bibl.title: Letter from F.M. Boldridge to Henry Rose Carter, January 20, 1925

div1.p: Boldridge describes malaria control in South Carolina.

div1.head: Letter from F.M. Boldridge to Henry Rose Carter, January 20, 1925
div1.opener:
WATEREE POWER COMPANY
CHARLOTTE, N.C.
ADDRESS ALL COMMUNICATIONS TO THE COMPANY,
AND IN REPLY TO THIS LETTER PLEASE REFER TO THESE INITIALS____________
Jan. 20, 1925.
Dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
Your interesting letter of Dec. 24th received in
due time and I would have answered sooner, but you know that a man in
the field is liable to let his correspondence drag a little in hopes
of having more to write about.

I have been very busy lately in as much as we have three
new projects under construction. The policy of cutting and burning
all trees and vegetation in ponded areas of this concern is indeed a
large undertaking, and as you have already said, is a most important
one.

The company decided last summer to raise the Wateree
dam six feet, this work started, one might say, overnight. We immediate-
ly began clearing out new area. The dam is about completed and we
are about through clearing although I am going to keep some crews at
work for some time yet. It is doubtful if this pond will ever be
allowed to completely fill up. I am going to make a careful and com-
plete study of this project for next few years and in meantime use
means to control breeding should any occur.

I guess you have seen a copy of regulations on im-
pounded waters recently passed by South Carolina State Board of
Health. They are very good and if properly complied with will
certainly reduce malaria in South Carolina. I am doing all in my
power to see that my people strictly comply with them.

ADDRESS ALL COMMUNICATIONS TO THE COMPANY,
AND IN REPLY TO THIS LETTER PLEASE REFER TO THESE INITIALS____________

We are raising the old Catawba dam (above Rock Hill
S. C.) forty feet. This is going to be about largest pond we will have.
(Shore line about 222 miles) We have about seven hundred men on this
clearing project and have two years to get clearing completed. This is
a very bad and malarious area and I am taking every means to stamp out
malaria in this community as a whole.

As to Rhodhiss, about forty miles below Bridgewater dam,
this project will be completed in about three weeks. This pond will
have a shore line of about eighty miles and the general terrain is
about same as Bridgewater. We are about through clearing this area
and I am now making my last inspection before dam is closed. We have
about twenty five sawdust piles in this area, mostly old ones, they will
not burn, so I am dragging them down and I do not believe they will
float or give me much trouble however, I am sure they will bear watching.

The company is cooperating with me fine in all my under-
takings and I can now begin to see results in some of my work.

My fish (gambusia) experiments have and are working
out fine and I have had good success in raising a large number of them.
There are great things but I dare not place to much confidence in them,
as my areas are large.

I will keep you posted during the year as to my work as
I know you are interested.

Certainly trust your health is improving, and I hope to
get up to see you before spring. Everyone here sends kindest regards and
WATEREE POWER COMPANY
CHARLOTTE, N.C.
ADDRESS ALL COMMUNICATIONS TO THE COMPANY,
AND IN REPLY TO THIS LETTER PLEASE REFER TO THESE INITIALS____________
Page 3.
Dr. Carter:
and someone is always asking about you.
